Shakespeare who?

What place does he inhabit in the modern world? (Thumbnail credit Credit: Swamibu)

Review: Boulle's Jewels

This little book, whilst written wittily, bypassed the first crucial step in producing non-fiction: defining itself. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Joseph Anton: a memoir

The book describes with great precision how nations discussed, sometimes ignored, and eventually fought for SRushdie, his novel, and the values that the whole episode embodied

Students and the Arts: the Norman Rea Gallery

The Norman Rea Gallery provides a great opportunity for students who are both interested in viewing and curating art

Hockney: Failing to see the bigger picture?

A subject of one of Hockney's art has been vandalised. Poppy Bullard asks what all the fuss is about. (Thumbnail credit Credit: Martin Beek)

Arts in York: what's on

A roundup of the interesting, the exciting, and the not-to-be-missed in York (Thumbnail credit Sebastian Faulk's Birdsong)

The Madness of Marmite

By James Bithell

Flamboyant Foodie, Ms Marmite, talks to Laura Hughes about cooking for therapy and gastro porn.

Calvin Harris - 18 Months: Album Review

The last year-and-a-half saw Calvin Harris score four consecutive Number 2 singles; Chris Morris explores the much-awaited record each of them collectively belong to.

Passion Pit: Live Review

Hailing from Cambridge, USA, Passion Pit's breakthrough single came in the form of indie-electro-pop 'Sleepyhead'. Genevieve Heah heads 30 minutes west to experience the Passion.

The Struggle against Stigma

Jonny Steinberg talks to Fiona Parker about narrative, biography and personalising an international crisis.

The Naked Baker: Pumpkin Pie

Fe Morizet is the Naked Baker, telling us why pumpkin pie need not be an affront to British taste buds

Singapore: A Republic of Eaters

In our first look at international food influences on campus, Amadea Ng talks about the diverse food culture of Singapore

The Recipe: Andy's Roast Lamb

Our Come Dine With Me winner, Andy Adenmosun, explains how to prepare his award-winning roast shoulder of lamb.

Ben Fogle: Adventurer. Presenter. Writer.

Review: The Hot Mikado

By James Bithell

"The most fun you'll have in the theatre all year". This is a play that doesn't aim to take itself too seriously. Tom Giles Reviews.

Review: Gambit

The new Coen Brothers-scripted comedy caper, boasting an all-star cast including Colin Firth, Cameron Diaz and Alan Rickman, lacks spark and fails to deliver the belly laughs you expect.

Review: Calendar Girls

Tim Firth's heart-warming adaptation of the famous film Calendar Girls leaves a new found belief in humanity. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Lady Lovely Lute

The Open Drama Night has produced an intriguing and insightful documentary, in which intimacy and intelligence is brought to a girl's experiences of brain trauma. Poppy Bullard reviews.

The Times they have a-Changed

By James Bithell

World Dylan expert and York fresher in 1964, Michael Gray, tells Sam Briggs about the life and times of Bob Dylan, and why we should be nostalgic about the sixties (even though we weren't there).

Review: The Hunchback of Notre Dame

Calvitto offers an adaptation of Victor Hugo's dark tale, effectively bringing out Quasimodo's psychological affliction. Catriona Lacy reviews.

Review: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf

Joe Lichtenstein brings Edward Albee's contentious drama to life with enthralling results. Lily Grant reviews.

Thomas Guerrier: One short film at a time

Thomas Guerrier talks to Steven Roberts about short film, his love of thrillers, and why the film industry isn't as scary as it looks. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Sebastian Solberg )

Currency and Controversy

By James Bithell

With the appearance of Nelson Mandela on South African notes breaking with convention, George Wood explores some of the weird, contentious and outright offensive designs to hit the world's presses.

A Toast to Christmas: Mulled Wine

Warm yourself up with the essence of a German Christmas Market, thrown into a mug of festive fever. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Alex Watkins)

Review: The Master

An enthralling and elusive film, The Master provides a nuanced study of a post-war America, in which two leads play out an electrifying relationship. James Tyas reviews

Equestrian Chic

If you are looking for a style to fit perfectly with the Yorkshire weather and a good investment for your winter wardrobe, I'd recommend leather riding boots.

Review: An evening with Gary Lineker

An exploration of the role of football in society, 'An evening with Gary Lineker' sees an effective combination of subversive humour and accurate social commentary. Ben Cross reviews.

Calum Macdiarmid: Commercialism and Creativity

By James Bithell

Calum Macdiarmid, fresh from the Aesthetica Short Film Festival's screening of his award-winning short film, 82, talks to Fliss Turner about aesthetics, art, and why he clings to expressionism.

Review: Wild East

TFTV's latest offering 'Wild East' is a captivating piece which kept the intimate venue on tenterhooks throughout. Lucie Parker reviews. (Thumbnail credit (c)Wild East)

A Victim to 'Masstige'

Collaborations between fashion houses and the high street are big news. Maison Martin Margiela launch their collection with H&M tomorrow, but at what cost to exclusivity? Francesca Butcher finds out. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Dierk Schaefer )
